conclusion: To determine if the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The x-axis represents time (t), ranging from 0 to 3 seconds. The y-axis represents velocity (v), ranging from -2 m/s to 2 m/s.

The graph shows three segments: From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s. From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s. From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s.
Displacement can be found by calculating the area under the v-t graph.
The area under the curve from t = 0 to t = 3 seconds will give us the total displacement.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second: The area is a rectangle with height 2 m/s and width 1 s. Area_1 = 2 x 1 = 2 m
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds: The area is a triangle with base 1 s and height 2 m/s. Area_2 = 1/2 x 1 x 2 = 1 m
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds: The area is a triangle with base 1 s and height 2 m/s. Area_3 = 1/2 x 1 x 2 = 1 m
Total displacement is the sum of the areas calculated. Total Displacement = Area_1 + Area_2 + Area_3 = 2 + 1 + 1 = 4 m
Since the total displacement is 4 meters, the particle has not returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
